sidebar.title: Provider networks overview
sidebar.para: This topic explains how to create a Neutron provider network.

A provider network is a virtual network created in the &kw-hos; cloud that is consumed by Helion services. The distinctive element of a provider network is that it does not create a virtual router; rather, it depends on L3 routing that is provided by the infrastructure.
A provider network is created by adding the specification to the &kw-hos; input model. It consists of at least one network and one or more subnets.

sidebar.title: &kw-hos; input model
sidebar.para: The input model is the primary mechanism a cloud admin uses in defining a Helion installation. It exists as a directory with a data subdirectory that contains YAML files. By convention, any service that creates a Neutron provider network will create a subdirectory under the data directory and the name of the subdirectory shall be the project name. For example, the Octavia project will use Neutron provider networks so it will have a subdirectory named 'octavia' and the config file that specifies the neutron network will exist in that subdirectory.

sidebar.title: Examples
sidebar.para: The following examples show the configuration file settings for Neutron and Octavia.
This file defines the mapping. It doesn't need to be edited unless you want to change the name of your VLAN.
Path: ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data/octavia/octavia_config.yml
sidebar.screen:
--- product: version: 2
configuration-data: - name: OCTAVIA-CONFIG-CP1 services: - octavia data: amp_network_name: OCTAVIA-MGMT-NET
sidebar.para: Input your network configuration information for your provider VLANs in neutron_config.yml found here:
~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data/neutron/.
sidebar.screen:
--- product: version: 2
configuration-data: - name: NEUTRON-CONFIG-CP1 services: - neutron data: neutron_provider_networks: - name: OCTAVIA-MGMT-NET provider: - network_type: vlan physical_network: physnet1 segmentation_id: 2754 cidr: 10.13.189.0/24 no_gateway: True enable_dhcp: True allocation_pools: - start: 10.13.189.4 end: 10.13.189.252 host_routes: # route to MANAGEMENT-NET - destination: 10.13.111.128/26 nexthop: 10.13.189.5

sidebar.title: Multiple Provider Networks
sidebar.para: The physical network infrastructure must be configured to convey the provider VLAN traffic as tagged VLANs to the cloud compute nodes and network service network nodes. Configuration of the physical network infrastructure is outside the scope of the &kw-hos-phrase; software.

&kw-hos-phrase; automates the server networking configuration and the Network Service configuration based on information in the cloud definition. To configure the system for provider VLANs, specify the neutron.networks.vlan tag with a provider-physical-network attribute on one or more network groups. For example (some attributes omitted for brevity):
sidebar.screen:
network-groups:
- name: NET_GROUP_A tags: - neutron.networks.vlan: provider-physical-network: physnet1
- name: NET_GROUP_B tags: - neutron.networks.vlan: provider-physical-network: physnet2
sidebar.para: A network group is associated with a server network interface via an interface model. For example (some attributes omitted for brevity):
sidebar.screen: interface-models: - name: INTERFACE_SET_X network-interfaces: - device: name: bond0 network-groups: - NET_GROUP_A - device: name: eth3 network-groups: - NET_GROUP_B
sidebar.para: A network group used for provider VLANs may contain only a single &kw-hos; network, because that VLAN must span all compute nodes and any Network Service network nodes/controllers (i.e. it is a single L2 segment). The &kw-hos; network must be defined with tagged-vlan false, otherwise a linux vlan network interface will be created. For example:
sidebar.screen:
networks:
- name: NET_A tagged-vlan: false network-group: NET_GROUP_A
- name: NET_B tagged-vlan: false network-group: NET_GROUP_B
sidebar.para: When the cloud is deployed, &kw-hos-phrase; will create the appropriate bridges on the servers, and set the appropriate attributes in the Neutron configuration files (e.g. bridge_mappings).
After the cloud has been deployed, create Network Service network objects for each provider VLAN. For example, using the Network Service CLI:
sidebar.screen: neutron net-create --provider:network_type vlan --provider:physical_network physnet1 --provider:segmentation_id 101 mynet101 neutron net-create --provider:network_type vlan --provider:physical_network physnet2 --provider:segmentation_id 234 mynet234
